{{About|the operation Yell in the United Kingdom|the global group, formerly Yell Global|Hibu}} {{Infobox company | name = Yell | logo = Yell Logo 2016.png | type = Subsidiary | industry = Online Marketing | fate = | predecessor = British Telecom | successor = | founded = 2000 | founder = | defunct = | hq_location_city = Reading | hq_location_country = Berkshire, United Kingdom | area_served = United Kingdom | key_people = Richard Hanscott, CEO
Oliver Wilson, CFO | products = Yellow Pages directory, Yell.com, Google PPC | owner = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = [[hibu]] | website = {{URL|business.yell.com}} }} '''Yell''', also known as Yell UK, is the subsidiary in the United Kingdom of global media organization, [[hibu]]. Operating in the online marketing space, as of {{CURRENTMONTHNAME}} {{CURRENTYEAR}}, Yell has created over 54,000 websites and managed 20,000 [[Pay per click|PPC]] campaigns for customers in the United Kingdom.{{cite web| url=https://business.yell.com/websites/| title=Websites| publisher=Yell Business| access-date=11 November 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://business.yell.com/ppc/| title=Pay-Per-Click| publisher=Yell Business| access-date=11 November 2016}} Yell has been publishing [[yellow pages]] since 1966, originally as a portion of [[Post Office (United Kingdom)|General Post Office]], and launched its Yell.com website in January 1996. ==History== [[Post Office (United Kingdom)|General Post Office]] first included Yellow Pages in its 1966 [[Brighton]] telephone directory.{{cite book| title=Classified Directory Advertising Services Market Investigation| publisher=The Stationery Office| date=June 29, 2006}} The General Post Office expanded its Yellow Pages throughout the United Kingdom in 1973.{{cite web| url=http://www.thephonebook.bt.com/media/pdf/dpa_sustainable_directories.pdf| title=Delivering Sustainable Directories| date=June 13, 2008| publisher=Data Publishers Association| access-date=11 November 2016}} In January 1996, Yell.com was launched as a local search engine for businesses in the United Kingdom.{{Cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/may/18/yell-boss-retires| title=City shocked as Yell boss Condron announced his retirement| date=May 18, 2010| author=Richard Wray| publisher=The Guardian| access-date=11 November 2016}} Yell announced a demerger from its parent company [[BT Group|BT]] in January 2001.{{Cite web| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/news/article-1559657/BT-confirms-mulling-Yell-demerger.html| title=BT confirms milling Yell demerger| date=January 28, 2001| publisher=Daily Mail| access-date=11 November 2016}} In May 2001, Yell was officially sold to venture capitalists [[Apax Partners]] and [[HM Capital Partners|Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst]] for £2.1 billion.{{cite web| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/news/article-1554939/BT-rings-up-16321bn-with-Yell-sale.html| title=BT rings up £2.1bn with Yell sale| author=Paul Armstrong| date=May 24, 2001| publisher=Daily Mail| access-date=11 November 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/news/article-1539176/Yell-edges-closer-to-flotation.html| title=Yell edges closer to flotation| date=April 30, 2002| publisher=Daily Mail| access-date=11 November 2016}} In April 2005, it was announced that Yell was partnering with [[Google]] to make local classified content available through Google's search engine.{{cite web| url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/510256/yellcom-joins-forces-google-uk-local-classifed-offering#| title=Yell.com joins forces with Google for UK local classified offering| date=April 19, 2005| publisher=Campaign| access-date=11 November 2016}} Yell integrated Apptus technology into its search engine to broaden is search capacity and enhance site development in 2008.{{cite web| url=http://www.ideon.se/pressrum/pressmeddelanden/artiklar/artikel/uks-local-search-engine-yellcom-chooses-apptus-technology-for-future-development/| title=UK's local search engine Yell.com chooses Apptus' technology for future development| date=January 11, 2008| publisher=Ideon| access-date=11 November 2016}} In 2009, Yell expanded its offerings to include Google [[AdWords]].{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/pda/2009/may/14/yell-gives-up-google-competition-adwords| title=Yell.com stops competing with Google, sells its adWords instead| date=May 14, 2009| author=Robert Andrews| publisher=The Guardian| access-date=11 November 2016}} Yell threatened Yellowikis with legal action in July 2006, claiming that consumers would confuse the two organisations.{{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/5169674.stm| title=Legal threat to wiki listing site| date=July 12, 2006| publisher=BBC News| access-date=11 November 2016}} In October 2009, an app was launched for Yell.com on the [[iPhone]] app store.{{cite web| url=http://www.totaltele.com/view.aspx?ID=449513| title=Yell.com App now available on App store| date=October 5, 2009| publisher=Total Telecom| access-date=11 November 2016}} Yell UK announced that it was changing its traditional Yellow Pages A4 format to a smaller size in February 2010 in order to improve usage of the directory. At that time, the directories contained an average of 54% recycled fiber content.{{cite web| url=http://www.letsrecycle.com/news/latest-news/news-in-brief-480/| title=Yellow Pages targets reduced waste with smaller directory| date=February 16, 2010| publisher=Lets Recycle| access-date=11 November 2016}} In October 2010, Yell moved in their new headquarters at One Reading Central, Reading, Berkshire, United Kingdom.{{cite web| url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/business/yells-new-building-something-shout-4221454| title=Yell's new building is something to shout about| author=David Millward| date=October 21, 2010| publisher=Get Reading| access-date=11 November 2016}} Richard Hanscott was named CEO of Yell in June 2011.{{cite web| url=http://www.thebusinessdesk.com/northwest/richard-hanscott-appointed-ceo-of-yell-uk.html| title=Richard Hanscott appointed CEO of Yell UK| date=June 29, 2011| publisher=he Business Desk| access-date=11 November 2016}} In May 2012, Yell's parent company Yell Group announced that it was changing its name to ''[[Hibu]]''. In August 2014, Hibu UK changed its customer facing brand back to Yell. They relaunched with updated websites, pay per click advertising and a new display advertising proposition.{{cite web| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/yellow-pages-in-u-turn-over-hibu-brand-9543137.html| title=Yellow Pages in u-turn over Hibu brand| author=Gideon Spanier| date=June 17, 2014| publisher=Independent| access-date=11 November 2016}} In November 2016, [[Glassdoor]] named Richard Hanscott to its list of Highest Rated CEOs in the United Kingdom.{{cite web| url=https://www.glassdoor.com/Award/Highest-Rated-CEOs-UK-2015-LST_KQ0,26.htm| title=Highest Rated CEOs - UK| publisher=Glassdoor| access-date=11 November 2016}} In September 2017, it announced that the Yellow Pages will be no longer published on paper from 2018 since it launched in 1966.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-41125865 |title= Yellow Pages to stop printing directory after 51-year run |publisher=BBC News |date= 1 September 2017}} The final edition will be published in January 2019. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://business.yell.com Official website] * [https://www.google.com/partners/#a_profile;idtf=6548250848;qury=Yell Google Premier Partner] [[Category:Telephone directory publishing companies]]
